title: No-deal Brexit would rocket government debt to 50-year high
text:
UK national income is already between £55 billion and £66 billion lower than it would have been if the country had voted Remain, the IFS said (Picture: Getty)

A no-deal Brexit would push government debt to a 50-year high, warn Britain’s leading financial experts.

A report from the Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) revealed that the impact of a no-deal is likely to send debt soaring to £100 billion.

Following last month’s spending review, government borrowing is on course to hit £50 billion next year, which is more than double what the Office for Budget Responsibility was forecasting in March.

However, in the event of even a ‘relatively benign’ no-deal Brexit, this figure could double, with national debt likely to climb to almost 90% of national income for the first time time since the mid-1960s.

The report comes as Boris Johnson increases funding for healthcare, schools and police, with chancellor Sajid Javid promising to ‘turn the page on austerity’ and create the ‘biggest spending boost in 15 years’ last month.

In its annual ‘green budget’, the IFS said that with a no-deal, next year’s ‘mini boom’ in public spending would be followed by another ‘bust’.

UK national income was already between £55 billion and £66 billion lower than it would have been if the country had voted Remain in the 2016 referendum, analysis by Citi bank for the IFS claimed.

Boris Johnson’s chancellor Sajid Javid has promised to ‘turn the page on austerity’ (Picture: Getty Images)

As a result of this, Britain has ‘almost entirely’ missed out on the bout of global growth over the last three years.

A no-deal Brexit is likely to bring about two years of zero growth – even with a ‘substantial’ fiscal and monetary response from the government and the Bank of England, Citi warn.

When the UK economy begins to grow again, it will still remain weak at 1.1% – 2.5% smaller than it would have been.

If Brexit is pushed back to a later date again, this will mean ‘very poor’ growth at around 1% a year.

But even if Britain leaves the EU with a deal, the economy will remain weak at 1.5% a year.

Ultimately, the best action to ensure economic growth would be remaining in the EU, Citi claimed.

Britain has ‘almost entirely’ missed out on the bout of global growth over the last three years, according to the report (Picture: AFP/Getty Images)

However, things become uncertain if Britain stays in the EU under a Labour government that’s committed to carrying out its policies on tax, nationalisation, share ownership and labour policy regulation.

It was impossible to say, in this case, whether the net effect would be better or worse than leaving the EU with a more ‘growth-friendly’ set of policies, Citi said.

IFS director Paul Johnson said that chancellor Mr Javid could not afford to offer any big tax giveaways.

He added that it was ‘crucial’ that, if Britain leaves without a deal, government measures to protect the economy are temporary.

Next year’s ‘mini boom’ in public spending would be followed by another ‘bust’ in the case of no-deal, the IFS said in its annual ‘green budget’ (Picture: AFP/Getty Images)

Mr Johnson said: ‘The Government is now adrift without any effective fiscal anchor.

‘Given the extraordinary level of uncertainty and risks facing the economy and public finances, it should not be looking to offer further permanent overall tax giveaways in any forthcoming budget.

‘In the case of a no-deal Brexit, though, it should be implementing carefully targeted and temporary tax cuts and spending increases where it can effectively support the economy.

‘It will be crucial that these programmes are temporary: an economy that turns out smaller than expected can, in the long run, support less public spending than expected, not more.’

description: A no-deal Brexit is likely to push government debt to a 50-year high of £100 billion, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies.
